Award.AwardTitle: Hydroperoxide, Nitrate, and Epoxide Chemistry of Biogenically-produced Alkenes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is a component of a broad community experiment named SOAS (Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study) designed to further investigate the photo-oxidation of the emissions (biogenic volatile organic compounds; BVOCs) of plants in the context of the atmospheric environment of the Southeast United States. The project will investigate the photochemistry of the dominant biogenic alkenes and their oxidation products, during a collaborative field experiment planned for summer, 2013 in Alabama. This site was chosen as a region where substantial BVOCs from vegetation mix with variable amounts of NOx and SOx oxidants emitted from power generation sites and other anthropogenic sources, covering a wide range of the natural reactivity exhibited by these compounds.

As well as the generation of photochemical smog through ozone formation, the subsequent oxidation products from BVOCs may contribute to the atmospheric burden of secondary aerosols, which have been implicated in regional climate forcing. Both the impacts on human health and human well being through climate change make the study of these compounds and particles a key aspect of current atmospheric chemical investigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic chemicals emitted from vegetation significantly impact atmospheric photochemistry. These emissions are dominated by a single compound, isoprene. Isoprene reacts rapidly with atmospheric oxidants, such as the hydroxyl radical. Under typical atmospheric daytime conditions, the reactive conversion of isoprene into more oxidized compounds occurs with a time constant of approximately 1 - 2 hours. The large flux and rapid oxidation of isoprene conspire to make its chemistry, and the chemistry of the associated products, of high global importance. The reactions have broad implications for regional air quality and global climate.

In this project, we have used field and laboratory observations to investigate the chemistry of isoprene. These measurements have been made using state-of-the science instrumentation developed at the California Institute of Technology and deployed to the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS) field site in Brent Alabama and to the University of Michigan Biological Station in Pellston, Michigan. These investigations, published in more than 20 peer-reviewed publications and in the Ph.D. theses of four graduate students, have substantially improved our understanding of how isoprene alters the global atmosphere. The newly elucidated chemistry is being incorporated into the air quality models used by the US Environmental Protection Agency, the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration, and their academic partners.

Modified by: Paul O Wennberg
